content.body: could use some rapid spam hiding/deleting on https://github.com/whatwg/webidl/pull/1421#pullrequestreview-2184595148 (warning, there's a graphic image)
Jeez

More than 10 years after the progress promises discussions and we still don't have a *great* pattern for progress signals...

My choices seem to be either: `createX()` returns a promise for a not-yet-initialized `X` object, which fires `progress` events and has a `ready` promise for when it's fully usable. Or, `createX({ progressCallback })`, which only fulfills once the `X` is fully ready.

The latter is a bit nicer but I can find zero precedent for it on the web platform...
content.formatted_body:
More than 10 years after the progress promises discussions and we still don't have a great pattern for progress signals...

My choices seem to be either: createX() returns a promise for a not-yet-initialized X object, which fires progress events and has a ready promise for when it's fully usable. Or, createX({ progressCallback }), which only fulfills once the X is fully ready.

The latter is a bit nicer but I can find zero precedent for it on the web platform...

content.body: Domenic: this in light of some of the chatter about people returning to XHR? I thought we had some kind of plan for that, though a general solution for promises also sounds interesting.
content.formatted_body: Domenic: this in light of some of the chatter about people returning to XHR? I thought we had some kind of plan for that, though a general solution for promises also sounds interesting.

content.body:
It's actually reflecting on some feedback on the former pattern which I've used in https://github.com/WICG/translation-api#downloading-new-languages .

A general solution for promises is probably not really possible. Or if it is, it'll be like AbortController and be something separate that just often integrates with promises.

What plan do you think we have? I vaguely remember some sort of FetchController or FetchSignal or something?
https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/607 isn't very enlightening
I guess https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/447#issuecomment-281731850 proposes a callback that gives you an object that fires events, that's even more complex, hmm.
Seems like this should be on the `Response` rather than the fetch?
content.formatted_body: Seems like this should be on the Response rather than the fetch?

content.body: Domenic: yeah, I think that's the plan of record. A callback that reveals a FetchObserver object upon which you can listen for progress, and can potentially monitor things like 1xx responses.
content.formatted_body: Domenic: yeah, I think that's the plan of record. A callback that reveals a FetchObserver object upon which you can listen for progress, and can potentially monitor things like 1xx responses.

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: no, that would not work for 1xx.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: no, that would not work for 1xx.

content.body: Might have to be careful about when it starts sending progress though to not give additional timing channels.
Hmm, for my case that's more complexity than needed, but maybe for future extensibility it's worth it??
What would be simpler that gives both download and upload progress? One callback for each?
What's the meaning download/upload progress for a 1xx response? didn't see that in the issue
* What's the meaning of download/upload progress for a 1xx response? didn't see that in the issue

m.new_content.body: What's the meaning of download/upload progress for a 1xx response? didn't see that in the issue

My case only needs download progress.
content.formatted_body:

My case only needs download progress.

content.body: Wouldn't `request.onprogress` and `response.onprogress` be simpler? Sure it doesn't support 1xx responses but isn't this good for the use cases authors care about? (Apologies if I'm missing something basic about this)
content.formatted_body: Wouldn't request.onprogress and response.onprogress be simpler? Sure it doesn't support 1xx responses but isn't this good for the use cases authors care about? (Apologies if I'm missing something basic about this)

content.body: Neither of those objects is stateful today, I'd kinda like to keep it that way

`FetchObserver` is still the best idea I've seen for 1xx responses, upload progress, download progress, priority changes (although maybe this one can be covered by signal?), and future esoteric HTTP features (e.g., trailers that appear mid-stream has been suggested as a feature at one point). But it is somewhat clunky and I can already see people complaining about it when compared to XHR.
content.formatted_body: FetchObserver is still the best idea I've seen for 1xx responses, upload progress, download progress, priority changes (although maybe this one can be covered by signal?), and future esoteric HTTP features (e.g., trailers that appear mid-stream has been suggested as a feature at one point). But it is somewhat clunky and I can already see people complaining about it when compared to XHR.

content.body: That's very probably a spec bug. The Dom parsing spec has a number of open issues on it which need reviewing and migrating to html or closing.

content.formatted_body:
fetch("test", {
  method: "POST",
  observer => {
    observer.onprogress = () => {
      console.log("finally");
    }
  }
});

const client = new XMLHttpRequest();
client.open("POST", "test");
client.onprogress = () => {
  console.log("been doing this for a long time");
}

content.body: It's not terrible, I think what people might prefer is an overloaded return promise. But subclassing promises is very much uncharted territory and prolly has its own issues.

m.new_content.formatted_body:
It's not terrible, I think what people might prefer is an overloaded return promise. But subclassing promises is very much uncharted territory and prolly has its own issues.

As in, naively I would expect this:

const observer = fetch("test", { method: "POST" });
observer.onprogress = () => {
  console.log("finally");
}

> <@lwarlow:igalia.com> Fwiw that fetch call seems like a pretty nice API? Though I feel like most developers won't mind the API too much at this point they just want a non XHR way to do it.
>

I vote for whatever we could agree on that gets something in the hands sooner rather than later. It seems like we have plenty of evidence that this remains a major pain point for developers, and addressing it will save developers from a lot of frustration, and save them a lot of time.
